subject: meta-google: Add common gBMC system init script
commitMessage:
meta-google: Add common gBMC system init script

Create a configurable sysinit script for all gBMC system to use. This
prevent difference in implementation during bootup between platforms.

The plan is to have each system that uses `gbmc-sysinit` to
replace the `gbmc_sysinit_helper.sh` and its function. It should be
flexible enough to support most current use cases. The service
dependencies will be configured with `service-override.conf` to make
sure that all dependencies are met on different systems.

The `gbmc_sysinit.sh` has `BIOS_PARTITION`, `BIOS_SIZE`, `BIOS_KEY` as
configurable variable depending on the BIOS image supported on the
different systems.

Tested with gbs:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/53993

Change-Id: I85f46894caf459c2dae7458faae71860845d3c90
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

Use a comment like `# shellcheck source=<path>.sh`

For the missing one, you can use `# shellcheck source=/dev/null`

Has this been tested (how much does it differ from the downstream version?) / what is our migration plan from our internal sysinit files? (I guess when this gets merged downstream, we'll make the downstream changes accordingly?

this was tested with gbs in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/53993.

Only the common stuff are here and everything else is configuration, so it supports everything that we have downstream.

The downstream change will look very close to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/53993 with the platform specific function implmentations.

there was some extra check before and has been removed. Was in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/53992/10 before.
Where does this come from?
removed.

LGTM, but would like to see if other reviewers had any other thoughts.

I think the change with gbs puts things into perspective, thanks

I don't believe any of the bios validation stuff belongs in openbmc, as we don't publish a tool for doing such validation. It would make more sense to have this script live at the same visibility as the tool.

I think it would also be nice to have a separation of concerns. You should make releasing the host from reset a separate package from the bios-validation routine as releasing the host from reset isn't inherently tied to using the specific bios validation code. It could be a target `host-reset-release-pre.target` in systemd where you have the `host-release.service` order `after`. Then have the bios validation logic be wantedby and before `host-reset-release-pre.target`.
ack. Will clean it up.

Actually the initial thinking is that we need the bios_validation workflow be available for the vendors to make sure that we all have common workflow (as much as possible)... but maybe the vendor don't need to test bios_validations? and we will include it when it is built as gBMC. The only issue here is that it will force the bringup effort to Google (which maybe is the move to make sure we keep a common workflow).

Nan, any thoughts?

It would be nice if we didn't need a template at all for this file and we just sourced anything provided in a `/usr/share/bios-validate/*.sh` that could override any specific functions that make sense.
will refactor it.
You probably want to make common implementations of these functions for `GPIO` + `DEV` being the fill in variables.
I think we actually have a common way to do this which we could upstream `was_ac_reset.sh`. We just need to implement the aspeed version.

you mean
```
#!/bin/bash
# The NPCM7xx defines the Reset Status Register as a hardware read only
# register that contains the reason for the last reset of the chip. A clean
# powercycle is the only time this is ever 0, which is when we want to ensure
# the host is off.
ressr=$(devmem 0xf080006c) || exit
echo "RESSR: $ressr" >&2
(( ressr == 0 ))
```
?

Isn't that `NPCM7xx` specific? Might not with work newer NPCM8xx (need to check).

Also there are some cases when we only check to see if the host is on/off instead of if it powercycled. It should be fine since the BMC bootup + host off is basically when it powercycle.

----

Actually, can we just assume that all our newer systems will support `xyz.openbmc_project.State.Chassis` with x86 power control or others. and use that instead. Not all of our system have it... so maybe not.

----

For Aspeed,

I found the system reset status
```
SCU064 System Reset Status Register Set 1-1
...
SCU07C System Reset Status Register Set 2-3
```
for AST2600. Maybe its the same thing.

Tom, do you know how Aspeed check if the system have reset?
